procedure: Osteochondral allograft transplantation, lateral femoral condyle, right knee
extraction_data.summary: 35-year-old male runner with focal chondral defect in the lateral femoral condyle of the right knee that was unresponsive to previous microfracture treatment. Patient underwent osteochondral allograft transplantation with a fresh allograft plug press-fit into the recipient site. Postoperative plan includes non-weight-bearing with crutches, continuous passive motion therapy, and formal rehabilitation beginning at two weeks.

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.description: Reverse total shoulder arthroplasty is similar to standard arthroplasty in that both components of the joint are replaced but the ball and socket portions of the joint are reversed, allowing the deltoid muscle to assume partial function of the rotator cuff. This procedure is typically utilized when there is concomitant rotator cuff disease. (Evidence: pg no: 7, L178-L180)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses shoulder arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of a congenital condition, acute or traumatic event such as fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). full_source.description: Total hip arthroplasty (THA), also referred to as total hip replacement (THR), involves removal of the femoral head and acetabulum and placement of a prosthesis anchored to the bone. The goal of the procedure is long-term pain relief and restoration of function. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L746-L749)
full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

documentation: Primary and secondary tumors of the proximal femur (Evidence: pg no: 24, L837)
Hip fracture or complications including malunion, nonunion or failed prior fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L838)
Failed previous hip fracture fixation (Evidence: pg no: 24, L839)
Avascular necrosis (osteonecrosis) with unresponsive severe pain (Evidence: pg no: 24, L840)
Revision of hip arthrodesis (Evidence: pg no: 24, L841)
Imaging evidence of significant joint destruction and cartilage loss, defined as Tönnis grade 3, modified Outerbridge grade III – IV, or Kellgren-Lawrence grade 3 – 4 (Evidence: pg no: 24, L844-L845)
Limited range of motion, antalgic gait and disabling pain of at least 3 months' duration (Evidence: pg no: 24, L846)
Pain with passive motion of the hip (Evidence: pg no: 24, L847)
Failure of at least 3 months of non-surgical conservative management (Evidence: pg no: 24, L848-L849)
Functional limitation secondary to hip pathology which interferes with the ability to perform age-appropriate daily activities (Evidence: pg no: 24, L850-L851)

exclusions: Indications for total hip arthroplasty other than those addressed in this guideline are considered not medically necessary (Evidence: pg no: 26, L937-L938)

codes.description: Arthroplasty, acetabular and proximal femoral prosthetic replacement (total hip arthroplasty), with or without autograft or allograft (Evidence: pg no: 27, L973-L974)

full_source.notes: All arthroplasty and acetabuloplasty/resection arthroplasty procedures are inclusive of synovectomy, removal of osteophytes, removal of loose bodies, manipulation of the hip, and release or repair of structures to gain entrance to the hip joint. (Evidence: pg no: 22, L749-L751)

full_source.description: A minimally invasive, biodegradable balloon spacer for treating massive, inoperable rotator cuff tears (MIRCTs). It preserves musculoskeletal and bone tissues, does not require the use of an anchor, and does not require a permanent implant. It is used as a spacer to eliminate friction between the acromion and the humeral head or rotator cuff to restore shoulder function and reduce pain. It is designed to biodegrade over the course of twelve months (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L93)
full_source.scope: Treatment of massive, irreparable rotator cuff tears (Evidence: pg no: 2, L90-L91)

documentation: Medical records documentation may be required to assess whether the member meets the clinical criteria for coverage (Evidence: pg no: 1, L40-L42)

exclusions: Unproven and not medically necessary due to insufficient evidence of efficacy (Evidence: pg no: 1, L37-L38)
full_source.notes: The current published literature is at high-risk of bias due to the small sample size, single-center focus, retrospective design, and lack of randomization, blinding, and control. There are device-related complications, and long-term studies are necessary as short-term results appear to degrade over time (Evidence: pg no: 2, L94-L97)

full_source.scope: This guideline addresses hip arthroplasty when performed as an elective, non-emergent procedure and not as part of the care of an acute fracture (excluding fracture of implant and periprosthetic fracture). (Evidence: pg no: 22, L756-L757)

original_chart:
OPERATIVE REPORT

Patient Name: Brian Thompson
MRN: 219876543
Date of Service: August 7, 2025
Surgeon: Dr. Rebecca Shah, MD

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:
1. Osteochondral allograft transplantation, lateral femoral condyle, right knee

INDICATIONS:
35-year-old male runner with focal chondral defect unresponsive to microfracture performed two years prior.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
1. Osteochondral defect, lateral femoral condyle, right knee

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:
Same as above.

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL:
Under general anesthesia with tourniquet control, lateral parapatellar arthrotomy was performed. Chondral lesion identified and debrided to stable vertical walls. Recipient socket prepared. Fresh allograft plug was sized on back table and press-fit into recipient site. Stability confirmed with knee through range of motion. Wound irrigated and closed in layers. Sterile compressive dressing applied.

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: 150 mL.
COMPLICATIONS: None.
DRAINS: None.
TOURNIQUET TIME: 55 minutes.

IMPLANTS:
Fresh osteochondral allograft plug utilized. Donor details not included in operative note.

POSTOPERATIVE PLAN:
Non-weight-bearing with crutches. Continuous passive motion for 6 hours daily. Aspirin prescribed for DVT prophylaxis. Formal rehab to begin at two weeks.

user_input_required.suggestion: Include pain severity on VAS scale (0-10), specific functional limitations (e.g., unable to run >10 minutes, difficulty with stairs), duration of symptoms, and failed conservative treatments

user_input_required.reason: Most payers require documentation of failed conservative management before approving surgical intervention
user_input_required.suggestion: Document specific conservative treatments attempted (physical therapy, NSAIDs, activity modification, bracing), duration of each treatment, and outcomes/failure of these treatments

user_input_required.reason: Objective evidence of pathology with specific measurements is required to establish medical necessity
user_input_required.suggestion: Include MRI report details, size of chondral defect in mm/cm, depth/grade of lesion (ICRS grade), and any associated pathology

user_input_required.suggestion: Include tissue bank source, donor age, tissue processing method, and allograft dimensions

user_input_required.suggestion: Document articular cartilage condition in all compartments, meniscal status, ligament integrity, and any other relevant findings

user_input_required.reason: Explicit documentation of how the condition affects the patient's function is critical for establishing medical necessity
